verses.text: In your wisdom, you made all things, and by your word, O Lord, you have power over all.
verses.comment: This verse echoes the idea of God's creative Word, foreshadowing the truth revealed in John 1:1 where the Word is Christ. The verse confirms God's absolute authority over creation and its order.

verses.text: For even if you willed it, you could have destroyed them with a single breath, but in your mercy, you spared them, sending wasps ahead as soldiers to punish them little by little.
verses.comment: God's measured justice and patience are evident here. The 'wasps' refer to God's subtle punishments rather than total destruction—a theme reinforced in Exodus 23:28.

verses.text: Not that you could not deliver the wicked over to righteous men in a single battle, or destroy them at once by savage beasts or a stern command.
verses.comment: This verse highlights that God's restraint is deliberate, choosing mercy and the path of conversion rather than overwhelming force. This patience of God is also seen in 2 Peter 3:9.

verses.text: But by judging them little by little, you gave them time to repent, though you were not unaware that their nature was evil, and their wickedness ingrained.
verses.comment: Here we see a clear revelation of God's mercy, giving room for repentance, foreshadowing the teachings of Jesus on forgiveness and patient love (Luke 13:6-9).

verses.text: For they were cursed from the start; neither through fear of you did they truly honor your ways.
verses.comment: God distinguishes between empty fear and sincere reverence. True faith entails more than outer obedience; it desires inner transformation, consistent with later New Testament teachings (Romans 2:29).

verses.text: Yet, as children you punished them, reminding them with gentle correction, as a parent disciplines a child, hoping for their repentance.
verses.comment: God’s discipline is purposeful and aims for restoration, not just justice—a theme echoed in Hebrews 12:5-11 about the discipline of the Lord’s children.

verses.text: But for your people, even when you punished them, you showed them great kindness, for you had sent them a glorious light to lead them forward, even amidst their suffering.
verses.comment: God’s mercy toward his own points to election and providence. The guiding ‘light’ anticipates the Light of Christ (John 8:12).

verses.text: In return for the harm they did to your children and for the slaughter of infants, you gave them abundant water in an unexpected way.
verses.comment: The miraculous water foreshadows the grace that flows from Christ, as ‘living water’ (John 4:10), especially in situations where human hope seems impossible.

verses.text: You showed by this that you judge our enemies with mercy and patience, as you call us to consider your goodness in hope for repentance.
verses.comment: This demonstrates a theology of hope linked to God’s patience, inviting all people to repentance and transformation.

verses.text: For while they suffered justly, having turned against you, you gave your people reason for hope, showing them how their adversaries were punished.
verses.comment: Deliverance is both judgment for the wicked and hope for God’s faithful, reinforcing both justice and mercy.

verses.text: For when our enemies drank the same water that brought relief to your people, they suffered, being destroyed by the same thing from which your own were blessed.
verses.comment: God’s providence can use the same element for blessing and for judgment. This concept foreshadows baptism, which both delivers from sin but judges unbelief (cf. 1 Peter 3:21).

verses.text: For instead of flowing rivers, they found the water foul, an example of your judgment that exposes the evil in the hearts of men.
verses.comment: Just as the Nile became blood for Egypt, God makes visible the consequences of sin. This is a call to spiritual vigilance.

verses.text: But even in their punishment, you did not answer them with anger, but showed them mercy so they might reflect and change their hearts.
verses.comment: Even in judgment, God's desire is not destruction but reform—a recurring theme throughout salvation history.

verses.text: They learned from their suffering—when punishment fell on them, they recognized whom they had rejected as true Lord.
verses.comment: Often suffering makes truth evident. This is a call to humility and recognition of God's sovereignty.

verses.text: The one whom they had before derided, now, in their need, they begged for help—all because they had received clear proof of your power.
verses.comment: God uses deliverance and hardship alike to draw all people toward faith and reliance on Him.

verses.text: But, even in their folly and rebellion, you showed patience, giving them opportunity after opportunity to turn back to you.
verses.comment: God desires even the wicked to turn and live; this reflects the richness of divine forbearance.

verses.text: For you, the Source of life, have in your hand all manner of creation—the four elements—and you can transform them as you will.
verses.comment: God’s sovereignty over the elements affirms His creative power. Early church fathers saw here a foundation for the possibility of miracles and sacramental signs.

verses.text: You can make what is without form take shape, and the invisible be made visible, according to your will.
verses.comment: Creation from nothing (creatio ex nihilo) is professed here—God’s word brings forth reality, underscoring the supernatural nature of divine action.

verses.text: For your power is unlimited, and you can use even slight things to humble the proud and mighty.
verses.comment: God often uses humble or weak means to accomplish His wise purposes—foreshadowing how Christ redeems through apparent weakness (cf. 2 Cor. 12:9).

verses.text: For the breath of your command can disperse them as with a word, or be consumed by your wrath, just as it pleases you.
verses.comment: Divine command is all-powerful, linking back to the authority of God’s Word, which carries through Scripture to Christ (see Heb. 1:3).

verses.text: For your Spirit is in all things, and you uphold all who are devoted to you.
verses.comment: The sustaining Spirit of God foreshadows the ongoing work of the Holy Spirit in believers (cf. John 14:16-17).

verses.text: For even the whole world before you is as a grain of sand on the scales, or a drop of dew in the morning mist.
verses.comment: This verse highlights God’s transcendence and the humility humans should have before the Creator.

verses.text: Yet you are merciful to all, because you can do all things; you overlook the sins of men, so that they may repent.
verses.comment: God’s patience is unparalleled, always leaving room for conversion and renewal.

verses.text: For you love all things that exist, and hate nothing you have made; for you would not have made anything if you hated it.
verses.comment: Affirms the goodness of all creation; evil is a perversion of the good, not a competing principle. This forms the basis of sacramental theology, affirming that matter can be used for divine purposes.

verses.text: How could a thing remain, unless you willed it? Or be preserved if not called forth by you?
verses.comment: God’s ongoing will sustains all that exists—hinting at the idea that creation depends constantly on God, an important theme for understanding providence and mystery.

verses.text: You spare all things, for they are yours, O Lord who loves life.
verses.comment: God’s love for life itself drives his patience and mercy. This prepares for the full revelation of God's love in Jesus Christ’s incarnation and sacrifice.
